p: Interestingly, from a socioeconomic point of view, there is a fivefold increase in GHG emissions between the lowest and highest expenditure quintiles for food consumption in the household. The carrying factor for this variation is the fact that lower classes have limited access to high carbon-emission food products such as red meat, and, to a lesser extent, a lower caloric intake per capita. In fact, unlike the current European or North American consumer, higher levels of obesity are found in Peruvian quintiles with higher purchase power.
